issue.title: [Form] broken submit behavior with zero indexed collection items.
issue.body:
### Symfony version(s) affected

6.3.6

### Description

https://github.com/symfony/symfony/pull/52021 introduced an issue when form collection contains zero indexed item.

When submitting form with zero indexed collection item its values are reindexed.

There was an attempt to fix this in [b769b77](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/commit/b769b779fe09e6cdb6e27a5b5185487902817c2a) but it was not enough for this case. As the original issue is closed. There is new one.

### How to reproduce

See reproducer with test case and proposed change: 
https://github.com/symfony/symfony/compare/6.4...jan-pintr:symfony-form-zero-indexed-collection-reporoducer:form-zero-indexed-col-reproducer?expand=1

### Possible Solution

Reproducer contains proposed change to `FormUtil::mergeParamsAndFiles()` function.

### Additional Context

_No response_

comment.body: Can you please send a PR so that we can discuss on the patch?

pull_request.title: Rename fixtures paths to be consistent
pull_request.body:
| Q             | A
| ------------- | ---
| Branch?       | 6.4
| Bug fix?      | no (maybe)
| New feature?  | no
| Deprecations? | no
| License       | MIT

There are currently two components with a "fixtures" (lowercase) folder,
* [Symfony/Component/AssetMapper/Tests/fixtures](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/tree/6.4/src/Symfony/Component/AssetMapper/Tests/fixtures)
* [Symfony/Component/Translation/Tests/fixtures](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/tree/6.4/src/Symfony/Component/Translation/Tests/fixtures)

So on case-sensitive filesystems the following exclusion in php-cs-fixer does not work.

```php
(new PhpCsFixer\Finder())
    ->in(__DIR__.'/src')
    ->append([__FILE__])
    ->notPath('#/Fixtures/#')
```    


Those are the files who are currently not excluded on case-sensitive filesystems

```console
php-cs-fixer list-files | grep fixtures
'./src/Symfony/Component/Translation/Tests/fixtures/extractor-ast/translation.html.php'
'./src/Symfony/Component/Translation/Tests/fixtures/extractor-ast/translatable-short.html.php'
'./src/Symfony/Component/Translation/Tests/fixtures/extractor-ast/translatable-fqn.html.php'
'./src/Symfony/Component/Translation/Tests/fixtures/extractor-ast/translatable.html.php'
'./src/Symfony/Component/Translation/Tests/fixtures/extractor-ast/validator-constraints.php'
'./src/Symfony/Component/Translation/Tests/fixtures/extractor/translation.html.php'
'./src/Symfony/Component/Translation/Tests/fixtures/extractor/translatable-short.html.php'
'./src/Symfony/Component/Translation/Tests/fixtures/extractor/translatable-fqn.html.php'
'./src/Symfony/Component/Translation/Tests/fixtures/extractor/translatable.html.php'
'./src/Symfony/Component/Translation/Tests/fixtures/extractor-7.3/translation.html.php'
'./src/Symfony/Component/AssetMapper/Tests/fixtures/importmap.php'
'./src/Symfony/Component/AssetMapper/Tests/fixtures/importmaps/importmap.php'
'./src/Symfony/Component/AssetMapper/Tests/fixtures/AssetMapperTestAppKernel.php'
```

This PR exclude files in both senstivie / insenstive systems.

labels.name: DX
labels.description: DX = Developer eXperience (anything that improves the experience of using Symfony)

issue.title: [Translation] What about putting translations in a cache pool?

labels.name: RFC
labels.description: RFC = Request For Comments (proposals about features that you want to be discussed)

issue.body:
It's common to update translation in production (with a cron). But then it comes to cache invalidation.

There is some hacky stuff in https://github.com/php-translation/symfony-bundle: 
* https://github.com/php-translation/symfony-bundle/blob/master/Command/DownloadCommand.php
* https://github.com/php-translation/symfony-bundle/blob/master/Service/CacheClearer.php

If we put the translation cache into a cache pool, it will become much easier to clear the cache, and them warm it up?

WDYT?

comment.body:
The creator of the cache component told me the cache component is extremely fast. Maybe you know him 🙃 ; With the PHP Array apdater, the overhead is really low, isn't? 

I said that, because it's boring to maintenant 2 things that does the same

issue.title: [http-foundation] Why is Request::getPayload() not checking content type
issue.body:
### Symfony version(s) affected

6.3

### Description

I ran into an issue with my integration tests in combination with PSR requests and using Laravel, see https://github.com/laravel/framework/issues/48828

I have an integration test testing a form submit, so content type is application/x-www-form-urlencoded and not JSON. getPayload does not check any content type and will try to decode it as JSON throwing an error.

But I guess it could also be seen as a potential CSRF vulnerability as a Rest API is only vulnerable to CSRF if you ignore the content-type and use session cookies.

### How to reproduce

I found it in a laravel application that uses PSR ServerRequestInterface in a controller and wrote a small integration test that does a form submit with content type application/x-www-form-urlencoded and url encoded POST body. But the real bug is just making a form submit request and calling getPayload()

### Possible Solution

2 possible solutions:
- make getPayload check content type?
- parse the body if its valid url encoded.

### Additional Context

_No response_

comment.body:
> for some reason $this->request is not filled in, but the body contains url encoded data instead

> Laravel is extending the Symfony request object.

i'd debug there first yes :)

issue.title: [http-foundation] Why is Request::getPayload() not checking content type
issue.body:
### Symfony version(s) affected

6.3

### Description

I ran into an issue with my integration tests in combination with PSR requests and using Laravel, see https://github.com/laravel/framework/issues/48828

I have an integration test testing a form submit, so content type is application/x-www-form-urlencoded and not JSON. getPayload does not check any content type and will try to decode it as JSON throwing an error.

But I guess it could also be seen as a potential CSRF vulnerability as a Rest API is only vulnerable to CSRF if you ignore the content-type and use session cookies.

### How to reproduce

I found it in a laravel application that uses PSR ServerRequestInterface in a controller and wrote a small integration test that does a form submit with content type application/x-www-form-urlencoded and url encoded POST body. But the real bug is just making a form submit request and calling getPayload()

### Possible Solution

2 possible solutions:
- make getPayload check content type?
- parse the body if its valid url encoded.

### Additional Context

_No response_

comment.body:
> > parse the body if its valid url encoded
> 
> It should do that already:
> 
> https://github.com/symfony/symfony/blob/ce48fbe3de4734101d98a98615c0afbd6e88c7d4/src/Symfony/Component/HttpFoundation/Request.php#L1519-L1524
> 
> IIUC it's possible to send JSON with form-urlencoded content-type, and getPayload() happily parses. Or what payload are we talking about now?
> 
> See also #50118, the suggestion is to check in controller rather then routing :S

Thank's I missed that $this->request should contain the parsed POST body. But for some reason $this->request is not filled in, but the body contains url encoded data instead. That will be hard to find out why $this->request is not filled in

My integration tests test if the library works in Laravel and Symfony and the test is using PSR requests internally and the library controllers are using PSR requests as well, but the side effect is that it does a lot of conversions from PSR request to the framework request object back to a PSR request. The Symfony integration tests work fine, but only the Laravel integration tests fail.

Laravel is extending the Symfony request object. Could it be possible that Laravel is not setting the $this->request property in all cases and that is breaking the getPayload() method?

issue.title: Improve PHPDoc descriptions of Attribute classes and parameters

labels.name: Good first issue
labels.description: Ideal for your first contribution! (some Symfony experience may be required)

issue.body:
### Description

Attributes are used in application codebase to configure specific behaviors. It's sometimes difficult, especially for a novice, to understand the purpose of an attribute or one of its parameters. To improve the developer experience, I suggest adding a description for each attribute class and parameter. Even if it seems obvious, it's a good idea to be explicit.

If you want to work on a class, or a set of classes, please comment this issue before to avoid duplicate work by someone else.

List of all attributes classes to track the progress (checked = doc is complete):

- [ ] [`Symfony\Bridge\Doctrine\Attribute\MapEntity`](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/blob/6.4/src/Symfony/Bridge/Doctrine/Attribute/MapEntity.php) #51987
- [ ] [`Symfony\Bridge\Doctrine\Validator\Constraints\UniqueEntity`](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/blob/6.4/src/Symfony/Bridge/Doctrine/Validator/Constraints/UniqueEntity.php) #51987
- [ ] [`Symfony\Bridge\Twig\Attribute\Template`](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/blob/6.4/src/Symfony/Bridge/Twig/Attribute/Template.php) #51987
- [ ] [`Symfony\Bundle\FrameworkBundle\Routing\Attribute/AsRoutingConditionService`](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/blob/6.4/src/Symfony/Bundle/FrameworkBundle/Routing/Attribute/AsRoutingConditionService.php) #51996
- [ ] [`Symfony\Component\Console\Attribute\AsCommand`](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/blob/6.4/src/Symfony/Component/Console/Attribute/AsCommand.php) #51974
- [ ] [`Symfony\Component\DependencyInjection\Attribute\AsAlias`](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/blob/6.4/src/Symfony/Component/DependencyInjection/Attribute/AsAlias.php) #51971

### Example

The [`Symfony\Component\HttpKernel\Attribute\Cache`](https://github.com/symfony/symfony/blob/6.4/src/Symfony/Component/HttpKernel/Attribute/Cache.php) class is the perfect example of what needs to be done:

- Add a description to the class header to indicate its purpose and what it does
- Add a description of each constructor argument

issue.title: Form DateType bug on PHP 8.2.12
issue.body: ### Symfony version(s) affected 6.3.6 ### Description https://github.com/php/php-src/issues/12533 ### How to reproduce ```class StatisticAppType extends AbstractType { public function buildForm(FormBuilderInterface $builder, array $options): void { $builder->add('date', DateType::class); } } ### Possible Solution _No response_ ### Additional Context _No response_

comment.body: Why does `Locale::getDefault()` return `admin` in your case?
